bioghist.p: John Hall (1736-1820) was an English mechanic and inventor. He was a close associate of the pioneers of steam power, Boulton and Watt. He came to America in 1785. He attended the Assembly Debates, and was present when Benjamin Franklin was elected president of Pennsylvania. He helped Thomas Paine build a model for a bridge over the Schuylkill River (a project that never came to completion). Hall later settled in Flemington, New Jersey, where he farmed and kept a store and tavern. He was a founder of the Flemington Library Company. He made frequent trips to New York City, Baltimore, and Alexandria, as well as a voyage to England in 1791.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of 62 journals kept by John Hall between 1785 and 1812. The journals begin with a description of Hall's voyage across the Atlantic, and continue on to describe in detail his daily activities, travels, and business.
